title: How to Use Fireplace Ash for Gardening

steps.headline: Understand the benefits of fireplace ash.
steps.description: Fireplace ash contains a valuable source of potassium. This helps plants resist disease. It can also improve the quality of flowers and fruit produced.

steps.headline: Clean out the ash from the fireplace and put into a suitable container for carrying outside.
steps.description: If the ash isn't already cool, leave it to cool completely.

steps.headline: Use on suitable plants.
steps.description: Fireplace ash is suitable for addition to roses and established shrubs and trees.

steps.headline: Ash is quite alkaline, and should not be used on acid-loving plants like Azaleas or Rhododendrons.
Add a shovelful of ash per plant.
Mix the ash into the soil well.
Repeat when the ash appears to have broken down well into the soil.

text: Understand the benefits of fireplace ash. Fireplace ash contains a valuable source of potassium. This helps plants resist disease. It can also improve the quality of flowers and fruit produced. Clean out the ash from the fireplace and put into a suitable container for carrying outside. If the ash isn't already cool, leave it to cool completely. Use on suitable plants. Fireplace ash is suitable for addition to roses and established shrubs and trees. Ash is quite alkaline, and should not be used on acid-loving plants like Azaleas or Rhododendrons.  Add a shovelful of ash per plant.  Mix the ash into the soil well.  Repeat when the ash appears to have broken down well into the soil.
